TopicTitle: Post your "KSP just gave up on physics" images here!

Articles.Content:
I recently pulled off the colonization of Laythe (with about 20+ quickloads since I'm not yet adept at Laythe aerobraking, and other fun atmospheric issues), and during a very laggy aerobraking maneuver (I didn't bother with Jool, I just went straight into Laythe at ~8.1 km/s), this happened:

That was at only 1x time warp, and somehow that spaceplane held on, even after this:

So, anyone else got some cool images of KSP just giving up on calculating collision, freaky orbital predictions, or other such things?

I bounced of the moon once and left Kerbins SOI.

no pics sorry was not pro enough, crashed straight afterwards (pc that was).
I've time warped through Kerbin...
After a crash a winglet flew off at supersonic speeds..
I had a 'Gravity' Moment....my space shuttle and station broke apart and flew off at ~23k m/s.

All of the above.

Plus (unfortunately no screenshot) I tried to turn a large and rather wobbly ship around in space and because it was taking long, I used physics warp. Then the ship bent like a bow and when I tried to use time warp to stop the rotation and bending, it froze in its bent and screwed up shape. After stopping the time warp, all parts skipped back to their original positions, but all struts skipped to positions where these parts were in the bent state. Only after entering and exiting time warp once again things returned to normal.

No pictures but here's the story:

Playing with KSP interstellar mod

Finally put together a ship with warp drive

Ready to depart from Kerbin for Jool at .5c

Coming around the day side, pointing at jool

Figured I was clear of the atmosphere

Warp drive engage in 5... 4... 3... 2... 1...

ENGAGE

Suddenly my ship is in several pieces

Still travelling at warp speed

Unable to stop them

No recent quicksave

They were out of the system within an hour

I cried a little

Hyperedit

(back in the forgotten 0.17)

Hyperedit

-terrifyingsnipofdeath-

(back in the forgotten 0.17)

Please tell me you got some pictures from Kerbin looking up at this chaos!

It might be just the mod needing updating, BUT SO FAR I'M THE ONLY ONE WHO GETS THIS BUG! :'D

link in case you live under a rock
When I pointed at Jool with a mainsail and a probe core with infinite fuel, when I reached Jool I just bounced off the atmosphere.
I have recently had an issue that happened while I was recording. give me a day or so and i'll have it up.
I bounced off of the moon out of Kerbind SOI.

I tried to make a vertically launched SSTO, but forgot to strut it. This happened after timewarping to apoapsis:

Edited January 15, 2014 by CalculusWarrior

I've posted this many times, but it's still one of my favorite screenshots. This is a botched aerobrake manuever.

Not one thing broke off of that ship until it hit the water (or whatever passes for water on Eve.)

I've time warped through Kerbin...

Oi've done that a lot with Jool setting up aerobraking then warping to the atmosphere assuming that the mandatory warp reduction occurs at various altitudes, only to find I've passed through Jool without any loss of speed. iw

I was looking through my old screenshots when I found this:

I have no idea
I launched this, an the physics started giving out shortly after it left the pad.

Unfortunately I only got it in video form, but I once had KSP decide that going from on-a-ladder to not-on-a-ladder due to said ladder getting retracted meant that you just lost all of your lateral velocity. Poor Jeb plummeted into the Mun. Tragic, but it made for a fun ending to the video.

Unfortunately I only got it in video form, but I once had KSP decide that going from on-a-ladder to not-on-a-ladder due to said ladder getting retracted meant that you just lost all of your lateral velocity. Poor Jeb plummeted into the Mun. Tragic, but it made for a fun ending to the video.

The same thing happened to be. I used it for Minmus landings using the J-pack

(or whatever passes for water on Eve.)

My new Fav Quote.
Strut free career mode. Sadly, it went poof when my improvised launch stablisers decoupled and collided with it.

I think this just feels....

Bad
No pic unfortunately, but when I placed a satellite with no propulsion on a geosynchronous orbit, it flew off, away from kerbin. It only happened when I was very close (286860m or closer I think)
What was the original plan for that?
